title: How to Reuse Balloons

steps.headline: Insert a plastic drinking straw through the colored plastic slip.
steps.description: Do so carefully to ensure the straw does not poke between the plastic. You should be able to insert the straw nearly all the way.

steps.headline: Slowly squeeze the balloon to release air.
steps.description: Be careful to not squeeze too quickly or tightly, as this might cause the balloon to pop. Listen for the sound or feel of the balloon deflating. If the balloon is not deflating, it’s possible you haven’t inserted your straw far enough into the balloon. Deflate the balloon away from your face, as Mylar balloons are filled with helium and not air!

steps.headline: Fold the balloon as you go.
steps.description: As the balloon deflates, carefully fold or roll it towards you. This not only helps ensure that all of the air gets removed, but also makes for easier storage and ensures that the balloon won’t tear or pop when you refill it again.

steps.headline: Remove the straw and finish folding.
steps.description: Wrap the string around the balloon to keep it from getting tangled. This has the added advantage of keeping the balloon tightly and compactly wrapped.

steps.headline: Take your balloon to a store for a refill.
steps.description: Once you’re ready for another celebration, bring your balloon to the store and ask them to refill it with helium for you. For a cheaper option, re-insert the straw and blow the balloon up yourself!

steps.headline: Research local hospitals, retirement homes, or elementary schools.
steps.description: If you aren’t familiar with the hospitals, retirement homes, and elementary schools in your area, now might be a good time to look them up and see if any of them might benefit from your balloons. Look for places that have young kids, an upcoming holiday, or another reason to have a celebration.

steps.headline: Receive permission to donate your balloons.
steps.description: Before taking your balloons to your chosen location, make sure they want the balloons. Some places, like specialty retirement homes or hospitals that have strict cleanliness rules, might not allow balloons for safety reasons.

steps.headline: Arrange a drop off time that works for you.
steps.description: Once you’ve received permission to donate your balloons, decide on a time where someone will be available to accept the balloons. Make sure that someone at the hospital, retirement home, or elementary school knows you’re coming.

steps.headline: Carefully load the balloons into your car for safe transportation.
steps.description: If you are donating a lot of balloons, ask someone to help you get the balloons safely into your car and prevent any balloons from flying away. Make sure you can drive safely and that your rear view mirror isn’t blocked.

steps.headline: Deflate the balloon.
steps.description: Pinch the balloon shut above the knot with one hand and use your other hand to pull the knot away from the balloon, creating a small piece of balloon past the knot that isn’t inflated. Carefully use scissors to cut the balloon and discard the knot, keeping the balloon closed. Release slowly, keeping a hold on the balloon as you go.

steps.headline: Snip the end of the balloon to create a tube.
steps.description: Once the balloon is deflated, cut the end opposite the hole to create one long, skinny tube. Maintain the rest of the balloon intact. For best results use long, skinny balloons, like the balloons used to make balloon animals.

steps.headline: Tape down a piece of string or elastic.
steps.description: For easier application, tape down one end of string or elastic and prepare to slide the balloons onto the bracelet from the other end. String has the benefit of being easier to tie and use, whereas elastic bracelets can come on and off without being damaged.

steps.headline: Thread the balloons onto your string or elastic.
steps.description: Carefully thread the balloon onto the string or elastic, scrunching it down as you go. Alternate colors for a more festive look.

steps.headline: Close the balloon bracelet.
steps.description: Once you’ve threaded enough balloons, tie the string or rubber in a knot and then cover the knot with the balloon ends for a “seamless” look.

methods.name: Using Mylar Balloons as Wrapping Paper

steps.headline: Cut the balloon open.
steps.description: Carefully puncture the balloon close to the knot and cut it open with scissors, letting the air drain out. Once it is fully deflated, cut along the side of the balloon so that you’re left with two circular pieces of balloon.

steps.headline: Make sure the balloon is big enough to fully cover the present.
steps.description: If it isn’t, try finding various balloons of the same color or design and taping them together, or use various colors for a more devil-may-care look.

steps.headline: Arrange the “top” of the gift carefully.
steps.description: Traditional wrapping paper has a repeating pattern that helps it look good on a gift no matter what. However, with Mylar balloons as your wrapping paper, you have to be careful to make sure you position the design in an attractive way.

steps.headline: Secure the balloon with plenty of tape.
steps.description: Mylar balloons can be a slippery wrapping material, so use plenty of tape. If possible, use heavy-duty tapes like colored duct tape or durable packing tape.

steps.headline: Wrap long cylindrical gifts by cinching the balloon with a ribbon.
steps.description: For tall gifts like wine bottles or water bottles, place the gift in the center of the balloon and guide the balloon up around the bottle. Cinch the remaining balloon above the gift into an appealing tuft and tie it shut with a ribbon.

steps.headline: Deflate the balloon.
steps.description: Pinch the balloon shut above the knot, so that there is a small piece of balloon that is not inflated. Cut with scissors and discard the knot while maintaining pressure on the balloon to keep the air from rushing out. Release slowly, keeping a hold on the balloon as you go.

steps.headline: Use a funnel to fill the balloon with either rice or flour.
steps.description: Deciding which filling you want mostly comes down to what you want your balloon stress ball to feel like. Once you’ve decided, slowly pour your rice or flour into the balloon through the funnel. Fill the balloon until it fits comfortably in your hand.

steps.headline: Remove all of the excess air.
steps.description: With one hand, pinch the balloon neck so that it is nearly completely closed. With your other hand, slowly squeeze the balloon until you can’t feel any more air.

steps.headline: Tie the balloon closed.
steps.description: With one hand, pinch the balloon right where your rice or flour starts. This hand will keep any air from leaking back into the balloon. With your other hand, stretch the balloon’s neck out away from you, and then tie it to itself.

steps.headline: Snip off any excess rubber after the knot.
steps.description: Leave enough space so that the knot will not undo itself!

steps.headline: Stuff the first balloon knot-first into a second deflated balloon.
steps.description: You want to create multiple layers to make sure your balloon stress ball doesn’t pop. By stuffing it in knot-first, you’re also protecting the knot you just created.

steps.headline: Remove excess air and tie the second balloon closed.
steps.description: Repeat the process of removing air and cutting the knot, making sure you aren’t cutting it too close.

steps.headline: Stuff your stress ball knot-first into a third balloon for maximum protection.
steps.description: Place the second balloon inside a third balloon, making sure to insert it knot-first again.

steps.headline: Remove excess air and tie the third balloon closed.
steps.description: This time, though you still want to minimize air, you do want to leave the end on! This is the outside of your balloon stress ball, so you want to make sure the end never accidentally unravels.

steps.headline: Repair as necessary.
steps.description: If the third balloon ever rips or comes off, just replace it with another balloon by repeating the process. Feel free to put as many balloon layers as possible, but remember that the more layers you have, the tougher the stress ball will be.

steps.headline: Deflate the Mylar balloon.
steps.description: Carefully puncture the Mylar balloon with scissors and release all of the helium inside. Keep the puncture away from your face so you don’t accidentally breathe any of the helium.

steps.headline: Cut the Mylar balloon into strips.
steps.description: Make the strips as long as possible, and avoid cutting them too thin. Your strips should be large enough to tie well to things and flutter in the wind.

steps.headline: Hang strips outside your windows to prevent birds from hitting them.
steps.description: If birds often accidentally hit your windows, you can hang Mylar strips outside of your windows to keep birds away.

steps.headline: Discourage birds by hanging your strips on your fruit trees.
steps.description: If your fruit trees keep being picked by birds, hang your strips with the shiny silver inside facing out. This can help scare birds away.

steps.headline: Deter deer by tying your strips to a fence.
steps.description: Strips fluttering in the breeze make noise and create shine that can scare deer away. For best results, tie two strips close together so they hit each other and make a buzzing sound when the wind is blowing.

text: Deflating Mylar Balloons Insert a plastic drinking straw through the colored plastic slip. Do so carefully to ensure the straw does not poke between the plastic. You should be able to insert the straw nearly all the way. Slowly squeeze the balloon to release air. Be careful to not squeeze too quickly or tightly, as this might cause the balloon to pop. Listen for the sound or feel of the balloon deflating. If the balloon is not deflating, it’s possible you haven’t inserted your straw far enough into the balloon. Deflate the balloon away from your face, as Mylar balloons are filled with helium and not air! Fold the balloon as you go. As the balloon deflates, carefully fold or roll it towards you. This not only helps ensure that all of the air gets removed, but also makes for easier storage and ensures that the balloon won’t tear or pop when you refill it again. Remove the straw and finish folding. Wrap the string around the balloon to keep it from getting tangled. This has the added advantage of keeping the balloon tightly and compactly wrapped. Take your balloon to a store for a refill. Once you’re ready for another celebration, bring your balloon to the store and ask them to refill it with helium for you. For a cheaper option, re-insert the straw and blow the balloon up yourself! Donating Your Balloons Research local hospitals, retirement homes, or elementary schools. If you aren’t familiar with the hospitals, retirement homes, and elementary schools in your area, now might be a good time to look them up and see if any of them might benefit from your balloons. Look for places that have young kids, an upcoming holiday, or another reason to have a celebration. Receive permission to donate your balloons. Before taking your balloons to your chosen location, make sure they want the balloons. Some places, like specialty retirement homes or hospitals that have strict cleanliness rules, might not allow balloons for safety reasons. Arrange a drop off time that works for you. Once you’ve received permission to donate your balloons, decide on a time where someone will be available to accept the balloons. Make sure that someone at the hospital, retirement home, or elementary school knows you’re coming. Carefully load the balloons into your car for safe transportation. If you are donating a lot of balloons, ask someone to help you get the balloons safely into your car and prevent any balloons from flying away. Make sure you can drive safely and that your rear view mirror isn’t blocked. Turning Balloons into Bracelets Deflate the balloon. Pinch the balloon shut above the knot with one hand and use your other hand to pull the knot away from the balloon, creating a small piece of balloon past the knot that isn’t inflated. Carefully use scissors to cut the balloon and discard the knot, keeping the balloon closed. Release slowly, keeping a hold on the balloon as you go. Snip the end of the balloon to create a tube. Once the balloon is deflated, cut the end opposite the hole to create one long, skinny tube. Maintain the rest of the balloon intact. For best results use long, skinny balloons, like the balloons used to make balloon animals. Tape down a piece of string or elastic. For easier application, tape down one end of string or elastic and prepare to slide the balloons onto the bracelet from the other end. String has the benefit of being easier to tie and use, whereas elastic bracelets can come on and off without being damaged. Thread the balloons onto your string or elastic. Carefully thread the balloon onto the string or elastic, scrunching it down as you go. Alternate colors for a more festive look. Close the balloon bracelet. Once you’ve threaded enough balloons, tie the string or rubber in a knot and then cover the knot with the balloon ends for a “seamless” look. Using Mylar Balloons as Wrapping Paper Cut the balloon open. Carefully puncture the balloon close to the knot and cut it open with scissors, letting the air drain out. Once it is fully deflated, cut along the side of the balloon so that you’re left with two circular pieces of balloon. Make sure the balloon is big enough to fully cover the present. If it isn’t, try finding various balloons of the same color or design and taping them together, or use various colors for a more devil-may-care look. Arrange the “top” of the gift carefully. Traditional wrapping paper has a repeating pattern that helps it look good on a gift no matter what. However, with Mylar balloons as your wrapping paper, you have to be careful to make sure you position the design in an attractive way. Secure the balloon with plenty of tape. Mylar balloons can be a slippery wrapping material, so use plenty of tape. If possible, use heavy-duty tapes like colored duct tape or durable packing tape. Wrap long cylindrical gifts by cinching the balloon with a ribbon. For tall gifts like wine bottles or water bottles, place the gift in the center of the balloon and guide the balloon up around the bottle. Cinch the remaining balloon above the gift into an appealing tuft and tie it shut with a ribbon. Creating a Balloon Stress Ball Deflate the balloon. Pinch the balloon shut above the knot, so that there is a small piece of balloon that is not inflated. Cut with scissors and discard the knot while maintaining pressure on the balloon to keep the air from rushing out. Release slowly, keeping a hold on the balloon as you go. Use a funnel to fill the balloon with either rice or flour. Deciding which filling you want mostly comes down to what you want your balloon stress ball to feel like. Once you’ve decided, slowly pour your rice or flour into the balloon through the funnel. Fill the balloon until it fits comfortably in your hand. Remove all of the excess air. With one hand, pinch the balloon neck so that it is nearly completely closed. With your other hand, slowly squeeze the balloon until you can’t feel any more air. Tie the balloon closed. With one hand, pinch the balloon right where your rice or flour starts. This hand will keep any air from leaking back into the balloon. With your other hand, stretch the balloon’s neck out away from you, and then tie it to itself. Snip off any excess rubber after the knot. Leave enough space so that the knot will not undo itself! Stuff the first balloon knot-first into a second deflated balloon. You want to create multiple layers to make sure your balloon stress ball doesn’t pop. By stuffing it in knot-first, you’re also protecting the knot you just created. Remove excess air and tie the second balloon closed. Repeat the process of removing air and cutting the knot, making sure you aren’t cutting it too close. Stuff your stress ball knot-first into a third balloon for maximum protection. Place the second balloon inside a third balloon, making sure to insert it knot-first again. Remove excess air and tie the third balloon closed. This time, though you still want to minimize air, you do want to leave the end on! This is the outside of your balloon stress ball, so you want to make sure the end never accidentally unravels. Repair as necessary. If the third balloon ever rips or comes off, just replace it with another balloon by repeating the process. Feel free to put as many balloon layers as possible, but remember that the more layers you have, the tougher the stress ball will be. Deterring Animals With Mylar Balloons Deflate the Mylar balloon. Carefully puncture the Mylar balloon with scissors and release all of the helium inside. Keep the puncture away from your face so you don’t accidentally breathe any of the helium. Cut the Mylar balloon into strips. Make the strips as long as possible, and avoid cutting them too thin. Your strips should be large enough to tie well to things and flutter in the wind. Hang strips outside your windows to prevent birds from hitting them. If birds often accidentally hit your windows, you can hang Mylar strips outside of your windows to keep birds away. Discourage birds by hanging your strips on your fruit trees. If your fruit trees keep being picked by birds, hang your strips with the shiny silver inside facing out. This can help scare birds away. Deter deer by tying your strips to a fence. Strips fluttering in the breeze make noise and create shine that can scare deer away. For best results, tie two strips close together so they hit each other and make a buzzing sound when the wind is blowing.

Do so carefully to ensure the straw does not poke between the plastic.
You should be able to insert the straw nearly all the way.
Slowly squeeze the balloon to release air.
Be careful to not squeeze too quickly or tightly, as this might cause the balloon to pop.
Listen for the sound or feel of the balloon deflating.
If the balloon is not deflating, it’s possible you haven’t inserted your straw far enough into the balloon.
Deflate the balloon away from your face, as Mylar balloons are filled with helium and not air!
Fold the balloon as you go.
As the balloon deflates, carefully fold or roll it towards you.
This not only helps ensure that all of the air gets removed, but also makes for easier storage and ensures that the balloon won’t tear or pop when you refill it again.
Remove the straw and finish folding.
Wrap the string around the balloon to keep it from getting tangled.
This has the added advantage of keeping the balloon tightly and compactly wrapped.
Take your balloon to a store for a refill.
Once you’re ready for another celebration, bring your balloon to the store and ask them to refill it with helium for you.
For a cheaper option, re-insert the straw and blow the balloon up yourself!
Donating Your Balloons Research local hospitals, retirement homes, or elementary schools.
If you aren’t familiar with the hospitals, retirement homes, and elementary schools in your area, now might be a good time to look them up and see if any of them might benefit from your balloons.
Look for places that have young kids, an upcoming holiday, or another reason to have a celebration.
Receive permission to donate your balloons.
Before taking your balloons to your chosen location, make sure they want the balloons.
Some places, like specialty retirement homes or hospitals that have strict cleanliness rules, might not allow balloons for safety reasons.
Arrange a drop off time that works for you.
Once you’ve received permission to donate your balloons, decide on a time where someone will be available to accept the balloons.
Make sure that someone at the hospital, retirement home, or elementary school knows you’re coming.
Carefully load the balloons into your car for safe transportation.
If you are donating a lot of balloons, ask someone to help you get the balloons safely into your car and prevent any balloons from flying away.
Make sure you can drive safely and that your rear view mirror isn’t blocked.
Turning Balloons into Bracelets Deflate the balloon.
Pinch the balloon shut above the knot with one hand and use your other hand to pull the knot away from the balloon, creating a small piece of balloon past the knot that isn’t inflated.
Carefully use scissors to cut the balloon and discard the knot, keeping the balloon closed.
Release slowly, keeping a hold on the balloon as you go.
Snip the end of the balloon to create a tube.
Once the balloon is deflated, cut the end opposite the hole to create one long, skinny tube.
Maintain the rest of the balloon intact.
For best results use long, skinny balloons, like the balloons used to make balloon animals.
Tape down a piece of string or elastic.
For easier application, tape down one end of string or elastic and prepare to slide the balloons onto the bracelet from the other end.
String has the benefit of being easier to tie and use, whereas elastic bracelets can come on and off without being damaged.
Thread the balloons onto your string or elastic.
Carefully thread the balloon onto the string or elastic, scrunching it down as you go.
Alternate colors for a more festive look.
Close the balloon bracelet.
Once you’ve threaded enough balloons, tie the string or rubber in a knot and then cover the knot with the balloon ends for a “seamless” look.
Using Mylar Balloons as Wrapping Paper Cut the balloon open.
Carefully puncture the balloon close to the knot and cut it open with scissors, letting the air drain out.
Once it is fully deflated, cut along the side of the balloon so that you’re left with two circular pieces of balloon.
Make sure the balloon is big enough to fully cover the present.
If it isn’t, try finding various balloons of the same color or design and taping them together, or use various colors for a more devil-may-care look.
Arrange the “top” of the gift carefully.
Traditional wrapping paper has a repeating pattern that helps it look good on a gift no matter what.
However, with Mylar balloons as your wrapping paper, you have to be careful to make sure you position the design in an attractive way.
Secure the balloon with plenty of tape.
Mylar balloons can be a slippery wrapping material, so use plenty of tape.
If possible, use heavy-duty tapes like colored duct tape or durable packing tape.
Wrap long cylindrical gifts by cinching the balloon with a ribbon.
For tall gifts like wine bottles or water bottles, place the gift in the center of the balloon and guide the balloon up around the bottle.
Cinch the remaining balloon above the gift into an appealing tuft and tie it shut with a ribbon.
Creating a Balloon Stress Ball Deflate the balloon.
Pinch the balloon shut above the knot, so that there is a small piece of balloon that is not inflated.
Cut with scissors and discard the knot while maintaining pressure on the balloon to keep the air from rushing out.
Release slowly, keeping a hold on the balloon as you go.
Use a funnel to fill the balloon with either rice or flour.
Deciding which filling you want mostly comes down to what you want your balloon stress ball to feel like.
Once you’ve decided, slowly pour your rice or flour into the balloon through the funnel.
Fill the balloon until it fits comfortably in your hand.
Remove all of the excess air.
With one hand, pinch the balloon neck so that it is nearly completely closed.
With your other hand, slowly squeeze the balloon until you can’t feel any more air.
Tie the balloon closed.
With one hand, pinch the balloon right where your rice or flour starts.
This hand will keep any air from leaking back into the balloon.
With your other hand, stretch the balloon’s neck out away from you, and then tie it to itself.
Snip off any excess rubber after the knot.
Leave enough space so that the knot will not undo itself!
Stuff the first balloon knot-first into a second deflated balloon.
You want to create multiple layers to make sure your balloon stress ball doesn’t pop.
By stuffing it in knot-first, you’re also protecting the knot you just created.
Remove excess air and tie the second balloon closed.
Repeat the process of removing air and cutting the knot, making sure you aren’t cutting it too close.
Stuff your stress ball knot-first into a third balloon for maximum protection.
Place the second balloon inside a third balloon, making sure to insert it knot-first again.
Remove excess air and tie the third balloon closed.
This time, though you still want to minimize air, you do want to leave the end on!
This is the outside of your balloon stress ball, so you want to make sure the end never accidentally unravels.
Repair as necessary.
If the third balloon ever rips or comes off, just replace it with another balloon by repeating the process.
Feel free to put as many balloon layers as possible, but remember that the more layers you have, the tougher the stress ball will be.
Deterring Animals With Mylar Balloons Deflate the Mylar balloon.
Carefully puncture the Mylar balloon with scissors and release all of the helium inside.
Keep the puncture away from your face so you don’t accidentally breathe any of the helium.
Cut the Mylar balloon into strips.
Make the strips as long as possible, and avoid cutting them too thin.
Your strips should be large enough to tie well to things and flutter in the wind.
Hang strips outside your windows to prevent birds from hitting them.
If birds often accidentally hit your windows, you can hang Mylar strips outside of your windows to keep birds away.
Discourage birds by hanging your strips on your fruit trees.
If your fruit trees keep being picked by birds, hang your strips with the shiny silver inside facing out.
This can help scare birds away.
Deter deer by tying your strips to a fence.
Strips fluttering in the breeze make noise and create shine that can scare deer away.
For best results, tie two strips close together so they hit each other and make a buzzing sound when the wind is blowing.
